title: Bit of Bollywood and Aboriginal love story equals new musical
text:
Map: Carnarvon 6701 
An Aboriginal man in the West Australian farming town of Carnarvon once wrote to a church in India looking for a wife. 
Now the child of that union, inspired by Dirty Dancing, is setting her parents' story to music in a musical called Bollywood Dreaming. 
It is arguably a case of truth being stranger than fiction but for playwright Andrea Fernandez, it is her family's story. 
"Dad was a little bit lonely and living in Carnarvon and he was looking for a wife [so] his brother suggested he writer to India, because they've got Indian heritage as well," Fernandez said. 
"He wrote to a church in India and they put an add in the local church paper, and dad got about 16 different responses." Love delivered in first letter 
It was a case of love at first letter for Fernandez's parents, which led to marriage and a new family in Carnarvon. Photo: Ms Fernandez's parents met for the first time in Kolkata (Calcutta), India. (Supplied: Andrea Fernandez) 
"Mum's was kind of the first [and] he just fell in love upon first reading her letter," she said. 
The incredible tale was the stuff of family legend, but when Fernandez started developing her skills as a playwright, it became something more. 
"This idea has been in my head for about the last eight years, and I only really got it onto paper last year with the help of Yirra Yaakin Theatre Company's writers' group," she said. 
"It focuses on that â€” the letters that he sent to India and the responses that he got back." 
While the musical is based on her parents' story, Fernandez found their caginess about details is leaving plenty of space for imagination. 
"I keep asking them, 'What did you write to one another?' but they've been very vague, so that's where I've had to be quite creative," she said. 
It has allowed her to mix her Yamitji heritage, with Bollywood styling and American popular culture to portray her parents' rich cultural fusion. 
"They are a little bit saucy [and] that's why Dirty Dancing has inspired this as well. They're not shy at all," she said. From page to stage 
Workshopping the concept at Yellamundie National First Peoples' Playwriting Festival pushed Fernandez's concept towards production. 
The event was part of the 2017 Sydney Festival and brought playwrights, dramaturges, producers and actors together to showcase Indigenous playwriting. 
"During this process at Yellamundie, it [began] turning into a musical and I've started writing music and some songs as well," Fernandez said. 
The developing work had its first public reading and Fernandez said the experience had been a huge boost. 
"Just being here and the process with a director, dramaturge, and all the actors... it's just flowing out of me, so I'm in the best headspace possible," she said. 
Fernandez hopes Bollywood Dreaming will be ready for production in 2019. 
"I'm about 40 pages in, but I reckon it will be another couple of years," she said.
